titleStmt.title: The apprentices of Londons petition presented to the Honourable Court of Parliament. Humbly shewing unto them the manifold abuses of their apprentiship, how the Frenchmen, Dutch, and Walloones, doe deprive them of their ancient customes, and former liberties in their trade. Describing also the bloody proceedings of the papists in Ireland, and to vindicate their masters losses by the Protestants there persecuted. Likewise in devoting the prelates, and lordly bishops, which insult too much over the whole clergie, as the whole kingdome besides. As also speaking of the Jesuites, that were condemned. Subscribed, and presented with the names of above 30000. apprentices.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The apprentices of Londons petition presented to the Honourable Court of Parliament. Humbly shewing unto them the manifold abuses of their apprentiship, how the Frenchmen, Dutch, and Walloones, doe deprive them of their ancient customes, and former liberties in their trade. Describing also the bloody proceedings of the papists in Ireland, and to vindicate their masters losses by the Protestants there persecuted. Likewise in devoting the prelates, and lordly bishops, which insult too much over the whole clergie, as the whole kingdome besides. As also speaking of the Jesuites, that were condemned. Subscribed, and presented with the names of above 30000. apprentices.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Apprentices of Londons PETITION Pre≈øented to the Honourable Court of Parliament.
Humbly ≈øhewing unto them the manifold Abu≈øes of their Apprenti≈øhip, how the Frenchmen, Dutch, and Walloones, doe deprive them of their ancient Cu≈øtomes, and former Liberties in their Trade.
De≈øcribing al≈øo the Bloody proceedings of the Papi≈øts in IRELAND, and to vindicate their Ma≈øters lo≈ø≈øes by the Prote≈øtants there per≈øecuted.
Likewi≈øe in devoting the Prelates; and Lordly Bi≈øhops, which in≈øult too much over the whole Clergie, as the whole Kingdome be≈øides.
As al≈øo ≈øpeaking of the Je≈øuites, that were Condemned.
Sub≈øcribed, and pre≈øented with the Names of above 30000. Apprentices.

figure.figDesc: map of part of the Thames and its tributaries relevant to London trade
figure.head: London.

div.head: The Apprentices of LONDONS Petition.
div.p:
THat the injuries, and abu≈øes done unto us are many, and the grievances, and oppre≈ø≈øions which hereupon we have ≈øuffered at ≈øundry times are manifold: wherefore we in the generall, and univer≈øall name of Us all, doe pre≈øume to pre≈øent our pre≈ø≈øures, and impendent injuries to your Honours, of whom onely we can expect redre≈ø≈øe, and of none other. For whereas this City hath bin renowned in the gazing eye of the world, and the magnificent enemies thereof applauded (both to the glorious fame of this State, and Kingdome) of all other Neighbour Countries, and Nations: Yet the Rites, and Liberties thereof being ≈øomewhat detracted, & abu≈øed, as al≈øo the Lawes and ancient Cu≈øtomes thereof being extenuated by ≈øome malignant, and ill-affected per≈øons, it now becomes as much deplorable in the ≈øight of all men: and whereas this City ≈øhould have been a Patterne of Piety, and goodne≈ø≈øe (regularly embraced) to the whole Kingdome be≈øides, it is now (by the means of divers ill-planted members hereof) become an example of Schi≈ømaticall di≈øturbances, and di≈øtractions. We therefore implore your Honours withall humility to re≈øtore our former Liberties, of which lately we
have been deprived and to regulate in an exact ratification the Lawes, and pri≈øtine Statutes of this City to the pre≈øervation of them (of which there is a requi≈øite nece≈ø≈øity in the≈øe perilous and confu≈øed times) in confirming the ≈øaid ancient cu≈øtome hereof.

And fir≈øt we be≈øeech your Honours to take into con≈øideration the intolerable abu≈øe of our Apprenti≈øhip: for where, we by coerion are nece≈ø≈øarily compelled to ≈øerve ≈øeven, or eight yeares at lea≈øt, before wee can have the immunity and freedome of this City to trade in: Tho≈øe which are meere Strangers doe ≈ønatch this Freedome from us, and pull the Trades out of our owne hands, ≈øo that by this meanes when our times are fully expired, wee doe then begin in a manner to ≈øuffer a ≈øecond Apprenti≈øhip to them, who doe thus domineere over us in our owne Trades.

This is the cau≈øe that ≈øo many breake every yeare, ≈øeeing that their Trading is ≈øtolne out of their hands to the great di≈øcomfort, and confu≈øion of us all. Moreover when we are out of our times, and ≈øhould then begin to trade in the world, we can get neither Hou≈øe, or Shop for our money, in regard that the≈øe Forraigners, and ≈øtrangers (as there are many French, Dutch, Walloones, &c.) will give any money to ≈ønatch them from us: and this is the chiefe≈øt cau≈øe, that hou≈øes are ≈øo exce≈ø≈øive deare in this City, and by this meanes many of us loo≈øe the lo≈ø≈øe of yeares, trade, and time, and are compelled to turne Journeymen. Wherefore we ≈øolely depend on your Honours favourable, gracious, and auxiliary opitulation, be≈øeeching you to re-erect that, which lately have been pull'd downe. And notwith≈øtanding this abu≈øe: there is a ≈øecond danger hangs over, viz. the fearefull dangers, perillous plots, and con≈øpiracies
which have, and are ≈øtill pretended by the Papi≈øts again≈øt us, which cau≈øeth a promi≈øcuous muting in this Kingdome. Their exulcerated envy (I confe≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ) have been oftentimes kindled in a ≈øp ‚Ä¢ rke ‚Ä¢ her ‚Ä¢ but (thankes be to God) their m ‚Ä¢ lice could never take fire here in England, untill now they are come to a full flame in Ireland, who≈øe Rebellious Actions are ≈øo inhumane, that it would draw teares from an adamantine eye, to thinke of their bloody, and Tyrannicall proceedings. Wherefore we humbly be≈øeech your Honours to take their groaning mi≈øery into your Chri≈øtian, and charitable con≈øideration, that the flouri≈øhing roote of Prote≈øtants be not ≈øuffered to be fully eradicated to the great di≈øcomfort of all men in the≈øe Kingdomes.

Moreover we earne≈øtly de≈øire your Honours, that you would be plea≈øed to ≈øend ≈øome ≈øpeedy ayde, and auxiliary a≈ø≈øi≈øtance unto them: for otherwi≈øe it will be a great detriment and dammage to divers in this City, in re≈øpect that mo≈øt of your Petitioners Ma≈øters have great ≈øummes of money, which many of tho≈øe Prote≈øtants doe owe unto them. In that regard they will be great loo≈øers thereby, unle≈ø≈øe they be re≈øtored unto their former e≈øtate, which will be a meanes to breake and undoe many in this Cittie, to the great di≈øcomfort and lo≈ø≈øe of your Petitioners. Therefore we be≈øeech you to revolve the manifold abu≈øes, which they have done, and unle≈ø≈øe you that are the reall Phi≈øitians of the ≈øtate (to purge this Kingdome from tho≈øe Sores that doth contaminate it) doe lay a re≈øtoratiue plai≈øter to tho≈øe mortall wounds, that are given by the Papi≈øts, they will ≈øuddenly canker, and turne to Phlebotomie.

Alas, 'tis unknowne what danger we are involved in, neither can we receive any comfort in our trade, in re≈øpect of the≈øe manifold perils which your Petitioners Ma≈øters are in, both in danger of their e≈øtates, and feare of their lives.

Omit not there fore we intreat you, ≈øo heavy, and weighty an importance, ≈øeeing that our nece≈ø≈øary dependance waites on your Honours, to relieve us. That after ages, and late po≈øteritie may en-chronicle ≈øo famous a deed, to your perpetuall Fame, and the immortall glory of this Kingdome.

But that we may con≈øummate all our greivances, and nece≈ø≈øities in one bundle, and that you may give your Verdict to each particular of our pre≈ø≈øures in one contract, we will proceed to our third griefe, expecting herein your favourable reflection on us, viz, the in≈øulting Domination of the Lordly Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and ≈øome others, who triumph with too much arrogant in≈øolencie over us, and their poore Bretheren of the Cleargie, and if plea≈øe your honours to looke backe on their mi≈ødemeanors, you may ea≈øily conceive how many great and un≈øufferable crimes they ≈øtand guiltie of, wherefore on bended knees (expre≈ø≈øing the humble allegiance of our hearts) we your Petitioners intreate your Honours with a favorable a≈øpect to view the ju≈øt de≈øires of this oppre≈ø≈øed J≈øarel, let not we be≈øeech you the≈øe Ab≈øoloms that in the time they had Pattents for their per≈øecution) made it no ≈øcruple to per≈øecute their owne fathers, let them not linger protract not time, but let not their puni≈øhments be any longer deferd, for they haue oppre≈ø≈øed the whole Kingdome, they were the fir≈øt cau≈øe of that Commotion in Scotland. But now (thankes be to God) concluded
in an exact peace, and univer≈øall Pacification: Yea they have been generally acknowledged to have beene the chiefe, and ≈øole cau≈øe of this Rebellious in≈øurrection in Jreland, to the Epidemicall danger of both Kingdomes, and the particuler griefe of each Subiect. Your Petitioners therefore, bearing the quotidian cryes of the people in what lamentable deploration they exclaime daily again≈øt the≈øe Lordly Bi≈øhops and Archbi≈øhops, doe be≈øeech you to revolve their in≈øultations, and what generall danger they have brought into the State, and wofull perils to the whole Commons; and doe therefore reque≈øt your Honours to clip off ≈øome of their illimited power, and extended authority. And that they would be devoted out of the hou≈øe of Peeres, for they hinder and procra≈øtinate the e≈øtabli≈øhment of Religion, which have beene a long time expected to the univer≈øall griefe of this whole Nation.

Moreover, we interpo≈øe with them the Romi≈øh Ie≈øuites, that ≈øting the Common wealth with their ≈øeducing allurements to the extenuation of our Prote≈øtant Religion, and the advancement of the Court of Rome: wherefore in re≈øpect that the Rebels in Ireland being their Confederates, doe ≈øo per≈øecute the Prote≈øtants there without any humane partiality, we be≈øeech you not to be too clement unto them, in ≈øparing them, e≈øpecially when the ≈øentence of the Law is gone upon them.

We be≈øeech you therefore favourably to con≈øider of our Petition, and we will forever labour with our full force, and power to defend your Honours to the vttermo≈øt of our might. Thus we humbly de≈øire your grave and judicious Coun≈øels herein, hoping your
generall a≈øcents, and con≈øents hereunto; which will be great ≈øervice done to God, great fame to the Kingdome, and e≈øpecially great credit to your Honours.
div.closer: And wee ≈øhall be bound to pray, &c.
